places.generalDescription: When you think of Ninh Binh, it‚Äôs not just the echoes of its ancient capital that resonate; it's also a captivating travel destination. Among its treasures is the Trang An Landscape Complex, a UNESCO World Heritage Site that enchants visitors with its stunning limestone caves and serene rivers. Often referred to as 'Ha Long Bay on Land,' this area offers breathtaking views and unforgettable boat rides through lush valleys.

sources.snippet: You get on a rowing boat from the pier then going through Hang Dia Linh, Hang Toi, Hang Sang, Hang Nau Ruou. You will be dropped off near Tran temple to climb nearly 500 stone steps to Tran Temple. After that you continue being on your boat through Hang Sinh, Hang Si, Ba Giot, Hang seo, Hang Son Duong and then visit PhuKhong, Bao Hieu temple.

places.name: Tr√†ng An Landscape Complex

reviews.text:
I've been traveling from Japan to Korea to the South and North Vietnam and this is one of the best experiences I have had on this trip.

I highly recommend spending a day exploring the caves and temples. We chose route 3 (for 3 hours) which visited the most beautiful and longest cave in Asian. But honestly, Hoa Lu has breath taking view everywhere you look. I'd definitely come back again when I visit Vietnam the next time.

What can I say? These many reviews already tell us about the beauty and marvel of this place.

One tip - we wanted to avoid large crowds so we ended up coming around 4 pm. It all started well, quiet and peaceful. However, when we were about to reach the highlight spot - the complex in the middle of the water, it was also pitch dark. And the journey back to the starting point was eerie. At one point, we were the only boat. Two other boats that were with us also left.

Our poor boat lady, and all of us tried to row now and then, but it wouldn't move any faster. ü§£ But it was also a story to laugh about now!

3 pm would have been the perfect time! Nevertheless, we enjoyed the tour. The booking office looked super pretty in the evening with all the colourful lanterns.

Well-organized entry point to a beautiful experience

The Tr√†ng An Landscape Complex ticket office is clean, efficient, and easy to navigate. You can choose from three river tour routes, each offering unique cave and temple views. After buying your ticket, you walk through an underground tunnel to the boat launch area, where you meet your rower and board your boat. The same spot is where your journey ends. Staff are helpful, signs are clear, and the process is smooth. A great starting point for exploring the scenery of Tr√†ng An

places.generalDescription: Bai Dinh Pagoda, located in the Gia Vien district, is a significant pilgrimage site that encompasses both an ancient and a new pagoda. The complex covers a vast area of 700 hectares and boasts several impressive features such as the largest bronze statue of Sakyamuni Buddha in Asia, the longest 500-Arhant corridors in Asia, and the biggest da hong chung (a giant bell) in Vietnam.

sources.snippet: Entrance fee: Free of chargeLocation: Gia Sinh Commune, Gia Vien District, Ninh Binh Province. The pagoda is a large complex comprising the old Bai Dinh pagoda and the new Bai Dinh pagoda, with many works that have achieved many records of Asia and Southeast Asia; such as the largest bronze Buddha statue in Asia, the pagoda has the longest Arhat corridor in Asia, the pagoda has the largest bronze statue of Maitreya in Southeast Asia. Bai Dinh Pagoda will be a tourist destination in Ninh Binh ideal for you on weekends.

sources.snippet: Bai Dinh Pagoda is Southeast Asia‚Äôs largest Buddhist complex. It consists of several temples and over 500 intricately carved statues of Buddha, including one that‚Äôs made of bronze and is 10 metres in height. Set within the Gia Sinh Commune, it attracts a huge crowd of local devotees and travellers looking to pay their respects and have their fortunes told by the resident monks.

reviews.text: Pagoda surrounded by the nature. Beautiful and calm place to meditate. Do visit the original pagoda which is amidst the jungle while returning to the main place. I Would recommend to take a guide if possible as they would explain you the history and the importance of this place in their culture. Worth visiting. Take the ticket that includes the eride to cover this place. Wear light and airy and carry enough water. If you are someone who hasn't wlaked in ages or not exercising, start doing that, as there is lot of walk other than the e rickshaw ride. Don't miss this place on the visit to Hanoi, Vietnam.

It began construction in 2003 and opened its door for visitors in 2010.  There are on going construction at present time June 2025.  Based on the size of the project it is very likely that there will be on going construction in the next 5-10 years.  With all that said, still worth to visit.  If you like walking take the 150k option which gives ride from the ticket counter to the sites and back, otherwise take the 300k option which will give you ride in between different attractions plus a feet herbal soak.  Overall, it houses hundreds of various ancient and new Buddha statues from Asia.  If you do the Chevy chase version, 2 hours; if you into Buddhism or history, it takes all day.  I enjoyed the visit and I think you will too.

Very interesting experience, a bit bizarre even given the size and emptiness. The park was almost empty and most of the park can be covered walking through shaded corridors. Staff is friendly and helpful. Don't believe any of the reviews reporting this as scam. you simply pay an entrance fee which includes the electric vehicle, and you can choose from three options 100, 150,300k. We thought it was well worth it.

There is a big restaurant with good vegan/vegetarian food for very reasonable prices. see photo

places.generalDescription: Tam Coc - Bich Dong is a stunning natural wonder located in Ninh Binh, often referred to as 'Ha Long Bay on land.' This picturesque area boasts an array of limestone caves and significant cultural sites, including the enchanting Tam Coc caves, the historic Thai Vi temple, and the serene Bich Dong pagoda. The region's breathtaking landscapes are particularly captivating during rice harvest season when fields transform into golden vistas.

sources.snippet: Entrance fees:Sightseeing tickets: 120,000 VND / person / one way ‚Äì Children under 1.40m: 60,000 VND / person / timeBoat ticket: 150,000 VND / time / boat (4 Vietnamese guests) ‚Äì 150,000 VND / time / boat (2 foreigners) ‚Äì Free for children under 3 years oldLocation: Van Lam village. Ninh Hai Commune, Hoa Lu District, Ninh Binh Province. Dubbed as Ha Long Bay on land Tam Coc has full of beauty like Ha Long and the biggest difference is that the beautiful rice paddy ranks as one of the most beautiful rice fields in Vietnam located between two mountain ranges.

Our trip includes a two-hour boat journey at Tam Coc Nature Reserve, or ‚ÄòHa Long Bay on land‚Äô, a photographic exploration of historic Bich Dong Pagoda, and a climb to Hang Mua, with incredible views over the paddies and river valleys of this beautiful region. sources.snippet: Tam Coc, meaning Three Grottoes, includes Hang Ca, Hang Hai and Hang Ba, concealing a whole world underground. To visit Tam Coc is to ride a boat following the  gentle Ngo Dong River, passing the golden floating paddy fields under the towering limestone cliffs, into the depth of the three caves‚Äô chambers. The first cave, Hang Ca, is the largest cave and the most beautiful one with the total length of 127 meters, lying under a limestone mountain towering on the water.
sources.shortName: 10+ Amazing Things To Do in Ninh Binh

sources.snippet: It boasts picturesque limestone karsts rising from rice paddies and the tranquil Ngo Dong River that flows through the area. During the rice season, the fields turn golden yellow, adding to the stunning views that earned it the nickname "Ha Long Bay on land". The name "Tam Coc" means "three caves" in Vietnamese, and it refers to the three natural caves that can be explored by a Ninh Binh boat tour.

sources.snippet: The most popular thing to do in Ninh Binh is to take a pleasant wooden boat ride down the peaceful  Tam C·ªëc River. In peak season, hundreds of these boats flock the waters carrying visitors between the mountains and through stalactite and stalagmite lined caves.

places.name: Tam Coc - Bich Dong

reviews.text: Tam Coc - Bich Dong is breathtaking! The boat rides through rice fields with mountains on both sides. Exploring the ancient caves was fascinating. The scenery was like a dream. Friendly locals and smooth service added to the experience. A must-visit destination in Ninh Binh, Vietnam. Highly recommended for nature lovers. Stunning beauty everywhere!

The boat ride at Tam Coc Caves was enjoyable and unique. one and half our ride in country boat guided expertly by Vietnamese women who skillfully pedaled with their feet. Visitors have the option to help row manually, adding an interactive element to the experience. The caves were dark with narrow passages and limestone formations, yet they will navigate smoothly without hitting the rocks. Overall a memorable experience .

The overall experience was good. For the first time I saw so many lotus while having the boat ride. The first cave was long and the other 2 were short and low in height so big people needs to mind their head.

Advise: bring umbrella to avoid from direct sunlight or untimely rain. I visited in hot summer that's why it was very hot in boat riding. Riding time is total 1.5 hours so enjoy the view.

places.generalDescription: Dia Tang Phi Lai Pagoda is a serene Buddhist temple nestled amidst pine-covered slopes, offering a tranquil space for contemplation and meditation. The pagoda's stunning architecture and peaceful ambiance create an unforgettable experience, providing respite from the bustle of daily life. The meticulously maintained grounds are tended to by dedicated volunteers, contributing to the site's beauty and tranquility.

sources.shortName: Things To Do In Ninh Binh

places.name: Dia Tang Phi Lai Pagoda

reviews.text:
A special place that brings an atmosphere of a real Japanese Zen temple. An incredibly well-groomed space. It is one of the most impressive temples I have seen during my trip to Vietnam. The territory of the temple is large, so you can climb for about 10 minutes to see statues representing different stages of Buddha's life. As a solo traveler, I was unsure if I should spend time at this temple standing aside from main touristic places, but I fell in love with it. It's a magical place I want to return to!

A main hall is dedicated to Buddha, with a large statue surrounded by several smaller ones. There are also two temples dedicated to Ksitigarbha Bodhisattva, and a beautiful Canon temple with a stunning statue. Between them all, you will find elegant altars with statues of Manjushri and other Bodhisattvas made from white jade.

Recommend h·∫ªre if you are interested in Buddhism culture and art.
Visiting the pagoda, visitors will be surprised by the path leading to the pagoda which is covered in gravel instead of being paved with red bricks like other pagodas. The layout of the pagoda also is different.
In front of the main chamber, twelve circles are drawn on the gravel background, featuring twelve human destinies.  The statue of Bodhisattva Ksitigarbha is placed solemnly inside the chamber.

On the right of the main chamber, the ancestral hall is a worshipping place for 42 generations of monks of the pagoda. There is a small hall dedicated to Quan The Am (Avalokitesvara Bodhisattva), Duc Ong and Duc Thanh Hien, a housing area for monks and nuns and Buddhists followers in the pagoda, a lecture hall where  Buddhist followers listen to the head monk's daily sermon and a guest house for tourists and those participating in retreats and experiences at the pagoda.
A must visit pagoda while in Hanoi, took 2hr by motorbike. Peaceful place with beautiful decorations

places.generalDescription: The Trang An Departure Boat Ticket offers a scenic and immersive experience through limestone cliffs, caves, and temples. The traditional hand-rowed boat tour provides three route options lasting between 2.5 to 4.5 hours, allowing visitors to explore breathtaking landscapes and spiritual sites while delving into Vietnamese culture. Many travelers prefer this over the Tam Coc Boat Tour due to its longer duration, better value, more cave exploration, temple visits, and spectacular views.

sources.snippet: Travel blogs often highlight the Trang An Boat tour, which takes you through caves and beautiful landscapes. The Mua Cave Viewpoint is another favorite, offering a 360-degree panoramic view of the region after a climb of 500 steps. Bich Dong Pagoda, a temple built inside a cave, surrounded by lotus flowers and impressive limestone formations, is also a must-visit‚Äã‚Äã.
sources.shortName: Things To Do In Ninh Binh

sources.snippet: Trang An complex is a mere 7 kilometres or 4 miles from the well-known Mua Cave viewpoint near Tam Coc, making it a top Instagram photo spot in Ninh Binh. Also, Trang An is a recognised natural and cultural world heritage site by UNESCO. Renowned as the homeland of King Kong, scenes from the Kong Skull Island movie were filmed here in 2017.

sources.snippet: Trang An boat rides are a top choice for those who love photography. The clear waters and tall limestone karsts make a magic world. The cliffs and caves add mystery to your pictures.
sources.shortName: Ninh Binh Pictures: Stunning Views & Landscapes

places.name: Trang An Departure Boat Ticket

reviews.text:
The boat ride here was truly an unforgettable experience. Although the day started off very hot, which affected our enjoyment a bit, things became much more pleasant as the sun went down. The scenery is breathtaking, and this place is definitely a must-visit at least once in a lifetime. Interestingly, some scenes from the movie Kong: Skull Island were filmed here, and you can still see some of the filming locations.
However, the boat riders are local villagers who don't speak English and don't explain anything during the ride. When I asked about Kong: Skull Island, they only responded with hand gestures. If I hadn't asked at the right moment, they wouldn't have even pointed it out.
The bamboo boat ride lasted around 2.5 hours, with one stop in between and a chance to explore a few beautiful caves. Despite the lack of communication, the peaceful atmosphere and stunning landscapes made this one of the highlights of our trip.

The environment is incredible and cannot be captured accurately in images. It must be experienced to be believed. You can also opt to help out in rowing the boat if you wish, which adds an additional layer of fun to the experience. There is also some wildlife, including monkeys. The caves are slightly worrying as you pass through them, and may not be for those with claustrophobia, but are otherwise very awe inspiring to go through and see the ancient stalagmites and stalactites. Overall, an extremely enjoyable experience.

Super fun experience, ducking through the low cave passages and seeing the beautiful scenery.
Was very busy with tours during August, and quite hectic getting on the boat as we were only a pair so had to be paired up with another couple on our route (minimum 3 people per boat).
Very smooth once on the boat, just make sure to wear suncream and a hat and cover your legs if you're wanting to go inside the temples. The people rowing do a fantastic job so tips are very kind!

reviews.text: An attractive destination you should experience when you visit NB. Ticket price is vnd 250k and you can choose route 1, 2 or 3 in nearly 3 hours on boat. Some boatwoman may suggest you to select route 2 or 3 because it would be pretty but each route has its beauty. It depends on your choice and your plan.

A great day for the boat rides. A little cloudy which made it cooler. The boats were small but four people fit easy with the rower.  So beautiful going thru mountains and caves with stops at many shrines and pagodas.

Our trip lasted about 3 hours and passed through 4 caves, some with low hanging stalactites so we need to watch our heads.  Unfortunately, we were paired with an elderly woman as our rower who couldn't help take photos, so most of our pictures turned out poorly. The first 1.5 hours were fun, but the second half felt never ending, so we ended up helping paddle in order to reach the finish sooner.

places.generalDescription: Bich Dong Pagoda is a captivating destination that beautifully blends history and nature, nestled against the stunning backdrop of mountains in Ninh Binh. This ancient tiered pagoda, part of the Trang An Landscape Complex and recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, invites visitors to explore its serene surroundings. As you ascend through its three levels, you'll encounter ancient shrines and temples dating back to the 15th century, each offering breathtaking views of the lush landscape below.

sources.snippet: Our trip includes a two-hour boat journey at Tam Coc Nature Reserve, or ‚ÄòHa Long Bay on land‚Äô, a photographic exploration of historic Bich Dong Pagoda, and a climb to Hang Mua, with incredible views over the paddies and river valleys of this beautiful region. We‚Äôll also be exploring some of the area‚Äôs fascinating craft villages to photograph the production of traditional ceramic art and stone carving. Learn the art of great travel and documentary photography while exploring one of northern Vietnam‚Äôs most scenic and culturally-rich provinces.

sources.snippet: Bich Dong Pagoda is an ancient tiered pagoda nestled between the limestone mountains in Ninh Binh, and it is one of the most scenic places in the area. Bich Dong Pagoda's ornate gate, with a stone bridge spanning across a beautiful lotus pond, is probably one of the most iconic sights in Ninh Binh. You can hike to several levels once you are at the temple.

sources.snippet: Located at the foot of a large mountain, Bich Dong Pagoda‚Äôs ornate gate is one of the most iconic sights in Ninh Binh. A stone bridge spans a large lotus pond, which explodes with bright pink blossoms in the summer. Just beyond the gate is a tranquil courtyard and a traditional Buddhist temple.

sources.snippet: As you arrive you‚Äôll see this stunning gate with the karst mountains in the background and if you‚Äôre lucky blooming lotus flowers in the pond. places.name: Bich Dong Pagoda

reviews.text: Visiting Bich Dong Pagoda was one of the most unforgettable experiences of our trip! The temple, built into the rock and surrounded by stunning nature, creates an atmosphere of tranquility and harmony. Climbing the steps between the levels of the pagoda, we enjoyed breathtaking views. The cave leading to one of the temple's sections was especially impressive. This place is definitely worth a visit ‚Äì an unforgettable atmosphere and incredible beauty!

The pagoda is beautiful and the entrance is free. Watch out for a parking SCAM. A guy in a uniform near the pagoda entrance points you into a shack  where an olderly couple gives out tickets and throws random numbers at people. They refuse to tell you how much beforehand, mumbling numbers like 1, writing 5 on the ticket and then asking 10 000 per a bicycle. That's way more than anywhere else. I just laughed and said no, it's too much, auntie and gave them 5k. They didn't get upset at all, meaning they're just trying what people are willing to pay. At the same time a couple with a motorbike was told to pay 25k for their motorbike even though they apparently agreed on 20k beforehand which is still way more than normal. It's okay wanting to make a little money while providing a shade for the bikes but just be honest and upfront, gee. Just park on the street/buy a drink at one of the "free" parking places.

Bich Dong Pagoda is an absolutely beautiful site and a must-see when visiting Ninh Binh. The pagoda's serene atmosphere, set against the backdrop of limestone mountains and lush greenery, makes it a truly memorable stop.

Be sure to wear shoes with good grip, as the stone steps can get slippery when wet. This is one of those places that captures the essence of Ninh Binh's charm - peaceful, scenic, and full of history.

places.generalDescription: Nestled about 35 kilometers from the bustling center of Ninh Binh, Chau Son Holy Mother Monastery is a hidden gem that beckons travelers seeking tranquility and beauty. Established in 1939, this stunning site showcases a unique blend of Gothic architecture crafted entirely from red bricks, giving it an ancient charm reminiscent of cinematic landscapes. While it's not a typical tourist hotspot, its serene atmosphere makes it perfect for reflection and relaxation.

sources.snippet: Admission and parking tickets are free from the monasteryOpen only to welcome visitors after the ceremony: Morning: 8:00 am ‚Äì 10:30 pm (Sunday to 10:00 pm); Afternoon: 14h30 ‚Ä≤ ‚Äì 16h30 ‚Ä≤ (Sunday from 15:30 ‚Ä≤ ‚Äì 16:30 ‚Ä≤) except Lent (around March) and retreat around early August. The monastery is a combination of Gothic architecture with completely red brick materials to create a very ancient monastery like the pictures only seen in movies. Tourists coming here should note that this is not a tourist destination in Ninh Binh; so please keep the tranquility and dignity and dress politely in the cathedral.

places.name: Chau Son Holy Mother Monastery

reviews.text: Beautiful monastery in the middle of Ninh Binh. Highly recommend checking out if you happen to be in the province.

Not our first time being in a monastery but definitely the 1st time experienced such a huge and friendly one in Vietnam.
located deep in the countryside behind the main road, Chau Son Monastery is less known in comparison to the Tam Coc Cave and all thr padogas in Ninh Binh. The monastery is surrounded by a very poetic and romantic natural setting with mountains, river, lake and plants. There is a very beautiful garden and a "cave" where the ritual ceremonies were held.
They only open the gate for tourists from 7.30 to 10.30 am. So better become an early riser for this one of a kind experience.

Visiting Chau Son Holy Mother Monastery was an incredibly peaceful experience. The beautiful blend of architecture and the serene environment provided a perfect setting for reflection and prayer. Highly recommend a visit for anyone seeking tranquility and spiritual enrichment.

places.generalDescription: Nh√† Th·ªù ƒê√° Ph√°t Di·ªám, also known as Phat Diem Cathedral, is a 19th-century stone cathedral located in Ninh Binh, Vietnam. It is situated amidst picturesque canals and rice paddies, making it a popular destination for spiritual tourism and cultural exploration. As the Catholic capital of Vietnam, this architectural masterpiece has stood for over 100 years and took 30 years to construct.

sources.snippet: Ninh Binh is the land of biggest Cathelic followers in the north of Vietnam.That is why you can view many churches on your journey to Ninh Binh, especially in Kim Son district.But famous & massive one is Phat Diem stone cathedral which was built of stones in 24 years by priest Tran Luc & local followers.The cathedral is a very beautiful mixture of eastern & western architecture .The whole construction constitutes an original set which Western Gothic architecture blends perfectly with that of traditional Vietnamese pagodas ‚Äì an interesting spot that can‚Äôt be missed in your trip to Ninh Binh

sources.snippet: An elaborate mix of Vietnamese religious architecture and European Gothic hints makes up one of the most beautiful churches in Vietnam. Phat Diem Stone Cathedral is an important building that took up to 24 years of construction, let alone the fact that the preparation phase took about 10 years to finish. The name Phat Diem literally translates to ‚Äòmanifesting beauty‚Äô, and the beauty comes from the materials and architectural style.
sources.shortName: Ninh Binh Trip: Exploring Scenic Spots in Vietnam‚Äôs Hidden Gem

sources.snippet: Bai Dinh Pagoda, the largest of its kind in Southeast Asia, and Phat Diem Cathedral show a mix of Buddhist and Catholic traditions, reflecting the area‚Äôs varied history.

places.name: Ph√°t Di·ªám Cathedral

reviews.text:
Superb experience! Vale la pena! ( It's worth the effort of waking up early, taking breakfast at 6am, leaving hotel at 630am to attend 730am Holy Mass at this majestic cathedral!)
It has Great history place for Catholic tradidions, French Church in the North of Vietnam. If you go to Ninh Binh, must visit for Christian especially Catholics!
Phat Diem Cathedral  consisted of one big central church and 4 smaller ones surrounding this main architecture. The churches were beautifully blended of the traditional Vietnamese culture and architecture and the Western religion reflecting in every single corner. The stand out is a pagoda style roof. The interior is very brightly decorated.
The interior has a well recognizable Romanesque-like arrangement with its central nave and side aisles separated by wooden columns, terminating in the raised sanctuary. While the interior particulars may be distinctly oriental or Vietnamese in most regards, the basic architectural structure are thoroughly rooted in the Roman basilica.
You will feel the youthfulness, vibrant atmosphere of Mass when compared to attending Mass at the western hemisphere churches where there are no young people willing to spend their Sunday morning at church anymore. Here 75% of the Mass attendance are young people,  kids and children!
We also met very nice people who greeted us with warmth.

I was expecting another church, but it was interesting and not like other churches I've seen in Vietnam or elsewhere.
Designed by Vietnamese.  Inside is all teak wood, and some of the wooden pillars are massive!!  The carvings were detailed.  Nice bluestone gatehouse at the front.
There was a church service starting when we arrived,  so could only have a brief look inside.

Intriguing looking Church - a blend of Vietnamese and French architecture. There are several chapels and grottos around the main Church as well. Have not seen a Church like this before - would recommend popping by from Ninh Binh if you have time to spare / if you have your own transportation.

places.generalDescription: Hoa Lu Ancient Capital, dating back to the 10th century, holds significant historical importance as the first fundamental government of Vietnam. Spanning 13.87 square kilometers, it witnessed pivotal events such as the union of Vietnam after the 12 Lords Rebellion and wars with neighboring dynasties. The ancient citadel is home to temples honoring emperors and royal figures from over a millennium ago, including Dinh Tien Hoang Emperor temple and Le Dai Hanh Emperor temple.

sources.snippet: Located away from the city and nestled between the mountains, this historic place is the perfect way to spend your time admiring the expansive gardens, unique architecture and stunning views of the surrounding area. Sense the impressive history of the empire that once ruled this land for more than 1000 years. Sadly the ancient citadels are no longer standing but you‚Äôll still find plenty of photo opportunities discovering the temples and shrines which were built in honour of the former emperors and their queens.

sources.snippet: Hoa Lu Ancient Capital is an unmissable attraction in Ninh Binh for history enthusiasts and nature seekers. The ancient capital has an extensive collection of well-preserved relics and monuments, including the temples of Dinh Tien Hoang and Le Dai Hanh, two former kings of Vietnam.

sources.snippet: Hoa Lu is an ancient capital city of the Dinh and Le dynasties that reigned over this area for many centuries. Hoa Lu is home to many old temples and antique structures that will give you a glimpse of what it must have been like in the first capital city of Vietnam during its peak.

reviews.text:
Peaceful and Spiritual Experience
I visited the Hoa Lo Ancient Pagoda during my trip to Vietnam and felt a deep sense of peace and spirituality. The place is serene, beautifully maintained, and filled with an aura of devotion. The traditional architecture, incense-filled air, and the calm environment offered a moment of quiet reflection amidst the busy city life.
It's a perfect spot to connect with the local culture, observe age-old rituals, and spend some soulful time. A must-visit for those seeking a blend of culture, history, and spiritual calm in Hanoi.

The place was nice, clean, and the pleasant weather added to the experience. There wasn't much to see in terms of ruins, but we appreciated the well-maintained environment and could imagine the rich history behind the site. Maybe we didn't have enough time, or perhaps not much of the ruins remain. But overall, it was a great visit. Would love to explore more of the surrounding area if given the chance!

Lots to see here, including a small museum and awesome pools and gardens. People were friendly and there were lots of tour groups but it wasn't too crowded. Bike definitely sped up the trip but not as much as advertised.

places.generalDescription: Nestled in Ninh Hai Commune, Hoa Lu District, Ecotourism park Bird Park Thung Nham is a haven for wildlife enthusiasts. The park is home to a diverse range of wetland birds, including storks and herons. Visitors can explore the area's caves and tropical fruit trees while taking in the stunning scenery.

sources.snippet: Thung Nham is famous for not only many kinds of birds living but also the caves on the water surface or mountains.Here are top attractions in Thung Nham that tourists can‚Äôt ignore: But Cave (having plaster stone fairy man statue, no light), Vai Gioi Cave (having 3 cave floors with many fanciful stalactites), Bird Sanctuary which you can visit by boat ride or walking nearby to view hundreds of birds, storks & herons flying around, especially in the late afternoon.This ecotourism resort is newly opened with accomodations, restaurants & fun activities you can take part in a day or overnight trip to Ninh Binh. You can nicely connect your biking trip to visit Tam Coc, Bich Dong & Thung Nham area. Birds Sanctuay in Thung Nham-Ninh Binh

reviews.text: If you wanna find a tranquil and beautiful place to stay for family or friends, this is the right choice. Visiting this ecosystem was one of the most unforgettable experiences of our trip! The temple, built into the rock and surrounded by stunning nature, creates an atmosphere of tranquility and harmony. Climbing the steps between the levels of the pagoda, we enjoyed breathtaking views. The cave leading to one of the sections was especially impressive. This place is definitely worth a visit ‚Äì an unforgettable atmosphere and incredible beauty!

The resort was pretty good. 2 caves and a big lake but only enough things to do for about half a day. The breakfast was also good, especially the pho. Our room was described as a ‚ÄúMountain View‚Äù room but the only window was full up against a rock face and so there was no natural light. I found this a bit misleading. We didn't eat at the restaurant as it was very overpriced compared to restaurants in Tam Coc which were fantastic.

One thing that annoyed me was that one of the manager approached on our first morning. He asked me to give the resort a review despite on being there a few daylights hours. I scanned the QR code and clicked 5 start but wasn't going to submit as it was not honest but he leant over me and clicked submit on my phone. I thought it was very rude and dishonest. In addition to this when we were leaving he put his phone in my girlfriend's face and asked how our stay was. We realised he was voice recording her completely un solicited. We have notice this sort of thing in Vietnam but never like this and from somewhere that wasn't to brand themselves as a high end resort, I thought it was a bit distasteful.

Came for a day trip to see the sights available here. The boat rides were great and the scenery was amazing.

We then decided to get the pass for the pool, however, we are now regretting it as 32 teenagers have descended on the place and it's turned into what can only be described as a kindergarten. They are screaming at the top of their lungs, sitting down on other people's loungers, and splashing people and their things. The adults accompanying them and the staff don't seem to care and are allowing this behaviour to continue. If you are expecting a relaxing experience it might be best to save your money and avoid this space. Not what you should expect from a resort.

Reply to business: There is no time like the present to review these guidelines. We are still here and the adults leading the group can be told how their kids should act.

places.generalDescription: Van Long Wetland Nature Reserve, located around 20km from Ninh Binh city in Vietnam, is the largest wetland area in the northern region. This tranquil reserve is home to a variety of rare animal and plant species, including the endangered Delacour's langur monkey.

sources.snippet: As the biggest wetland area in the north of Vietnam, Van Long nature reserve is characterised by a nice limestone outcrop setting on the swamp ‚Äì the living places of rare monkeys on Vietnam Red Book ‚Äì Delacour Langur.It is great on the boat trip along the mountains if you can view them running around on the mountain slopes.Van Long is also the land attracting a lot of migrating birds in the winter time from the North so if you visit this wetland in the winter ( from November to April), you can witness thousand of birds, heron, storks flying around to make a beautiful scene like the one in latest ‚ÄúKong: Skull island‚Äù movie which was set in Van Long. Further detailed in this article. >>>>>>>Recommended Ninh Binh day trips from Hanoi :
sources.shortName: Top attractions in Ninh Binh |The list of places to see & visit in a trip to Ninh Binh

sources.snippet: Standing amid the stunning limestone mountains in Ninh Binh, Van Long Nature Reserve is one of the few wetlands in the area that are known for their abundance of bird species and other rare animals like the endangered Delacour's langurs. The nature reserve is another prime place to go on a boat ride, but this time, with fewer people than the Trang An boat ride, you will experience the wetlands' nature in all its glory. The boat ride should cost around 3 - 5 USD, which takes about 1.5 hours to complete.
sources.shortName: Discover Ninh Binh: Top 8 Experiences You Can't Miss

sources.snippet: Entrance feesSightseeing ticket: 20,000 VND / personBoat ticket: 60,000 VND / boat / 2 guestsLocation: Gia Van commune, Gia Vien district, Ninh Binh province. If you are a nature lover, Van Long lagoon is an ideal destination, the largest wetland nature reserve in the Northern Delta. Van Long is surrounded by mountains and a naturally flooded lagoon, where the number of white-rump langurs currently exists in the country; and is also home to many other animals.
sources.shortName: 12 Top-Rated Tourist Attractions in Ninh Binh

sources.snippet: In recent years, Van Long Nature Reserve has appeared on many visitors‚Äô bucket list of Ninh Binh‚Äôs top things to do. Vietnamese people have this saying to describe the natural beauty: the mountains and the water found harmony, and that harmony is found in Van Long. Served as a nature reserve with a wide range of fauna and flora species, including the rare species listed in Red Book and one of them are the silver langurs.
sources.shortName: 10+ Amazing Things To Do in Ninh Binh

sources.snippet: Van Long Wetland Nature Reserve is the largest wetland nature reserve in the northern part of Vietnam and is popular for hiking and birdwatching. It is home to a wide variety of flora and fauna, including several endangered species like the Delacour's langur. The best way to experience the reserve is by taking a traditional sampan boat tour.
sources.shortName: 14 Things to do in Ninh Binh Vietnam 2025

sources.snippet: There are many villages in the area near the reserve, offering plenty of opportunities for pictures of rural life as the sun goes down. Farmers will be bringing in their cattle, buffaloes taking a dip in the rivers and schoolchildren cycling home along the dykes. It‚Äôs a fantastic way to wrap up this adventure through classic lowland Vietnam.

At this time you also have the opportunity to enjoy the soothing pure white of the mop season here.

sources.snippet: Set in the shadow of a massive limestone mountain the Van Long Wetlands is a magical marshy reserve. The reserve is extremely popular with bird watchers and home to a wide variety of feathered friends. Book a boat tour to discover remote scenery, and gain a special glimpse into this serene setting.

places.name: Van Long Wetland Nature Reserve

reviews.text:
We had a great time here. It is much quieter and cheaper than Tam Coc and Trang An.

In order to visit the nature reserve you need to buy tickets for a boat trip. The tickets cost 200k per boat. We enjoyed 1h and a half of scenic views. We saw numerous species of birds, but unfortunately no monkeys üò¢. It seems like it's a 50/50 chance you'd get to see one. We enjoyed the ride nevertheless.

We gave the lady on the boat a tip because she did a great job showing us around. Unfortunately, she seemed displeased with the amount, and was not shy to show us her dissatisfaction. I am not sure if they are used to receiving way bigger tips....or why she was so upset. Either way, it was a good experience.

I enjoyed every minute of the boat ride. I can't believe these guys can row a boat for 1 hour and 30 minutes straight. No breaks. While also managing to take loads of photos of me. Logic does not compute. I tried rowing for a bit and within 30 seconds my arms went up in flames, the burn was real.

I asked him loads of questions in English, which he probably didn't understand, but that's okay, because I didn't understand any of his answers either. It was still really nice talking to him, even if nothing made any sense.

I gave him all my money. He deserves all my money. He is far superior. What a legend.

Sitting in a boat in full sun exposure without any shadow cover (they should really add one), on an uncomfortable seat - a wooden plank - to see a not very varying landscape while being rowed by ladies who don't speak any English ‚Ä¶ the pictures taken are beautiful but this felt like paying for suffering if you can't stand direct sun burn. As concerns animals, we saw a bird, a dragonfly, some snail eggs, some cows and dead fish, nothing spectacular and none of the species in the pictures with which they attract visitors. Unless you have plenty of time, I would not recommend.

places.generalDescription: Cuc Phuong National Park is a vast conservation area spanning 25,000 hectares across Ninh Binh, Hoa Binh, and Thanh Hoa provinces in Vietnam. It boasts a diverse range of flora and fauna typical of tropical rainforests, including highly endangered species. The park features ancient trees, the Con Moong Cave with fossils, and the Cave of prehistoric man.

sources.snippet: Cuc Phuong National Park is considered to be the first established national park in the country and the largest nature reserve spanning more than 200 km. The national park is also home to many rare flora and fauna and critically endangered species like Delacour's langur, golden-headed langur, and black-crested gibbon. Although you can explore parts of Cuc Phuong National Park on a bike, the national park is best done on foot, and to truly do justice to the place, I highly recommend going on an organized tour that will help guide you through these lush valleys and charming forests.

sources.snippet: Cuc Phuongis the most famous national park in Vietnam, also the oldest one and the largest nature reserve, spreading out on three provinces. Cuc Phuong is home to a biodiversity of flora and fauna, including 97 species of mammals, langurs; 300 species of birds, 11 species of fish; 2,000 species of vascular plants, and thousands of species of insects.

sources.snippet: As Vietnam‚Äôs first and largest national park, Cuc Phuong boasts a respectable diversity of flora and fauna. places.name: Cuc Phuong National Park

reviews.text: Excellent, satisfying a peaceful day exploring the park. We rented bicycles at the park entrance (150k all day until 6-7pm). We cycled to the far end which was fairly challenging, took about 1:45 with some short stops, taking it easy on the downhill stretches as the ground was wet) - the road is overall uphill on the way into the park. Enjoyed a rest for coffee at the park centre, then hiked the loop at the end (took 2:20 including time exploring the cave). Almost had the hike to ourselves. Lunch back at the park centre was fresh, cheap and enjoyable. Cycled back (very grateful for the downhill gradient, apart from a few steep uphill sections) and explored prehistoric cave on the way. Long and tiring day but very worthwhile. The road was mostly free from any traffic - only a few cars and motorbikes passed us all day - and the road surface was good.

This National park is purely amazing. Take a scooter (or a bike) and ride through it, enyoing the nature and jungle in its purest form! I came up from Ninh Binh and can only recommend doing so if you are in the area it is a quite relaxing drive with the scooter without any traffic.

Make sure to visit the prehistoric human caves and the ancient tree. The tree might not sound too spectacular, but it was probably my favorite thing to do! You have to take a small path into the jungle and you can continue on this path deeper into the jungle if you want (a guide i met on the way told me it goes on for 10km). It is really amazing to experince the jungle this way and no worries, you cannot get lost, the path is quite easy to follow.

At the end of the road through the park you can find a restaurant for lunch.

There is also a monkey reservatory but i was too late to visit (it is only open from 13:30 to 16:30).

I highly recommend visitinf this park if you are in the Ninh Binh area!

We stayed here for five nights. The highlights were the beautiful forest setting, friendly staff, and welcoming atmosphere. The scenery was stunning, and we had an excellent hiking experience with rangers guiding us through the trails.
However, there were some challenges. The insect bites took weeks to heal, and leeches were abundant, we counted around 35 in a single day of hiking, fall down several times as we got a bit of rain and wet.. Outch :). It was still an adventurous and memorable experience, but proper boots and leech socks are essential. Even with those, we were bitten quite badly.

We didn't encounter any large wildlife, but the night safaris were still a highlight. Thousands of fireflies lit up the forest, a beautiful sight. We also observed a few snakes chasing frogs, birds settling into the leaves for rest, and a variety of fascinating insects and bugs. Toward the end, we were lucky to come across a group of deer.

The food at the restaurant was generally good, though there is room for improvement. Overall, a rewarding stay for nature lovers, but be prepared for the elements.

places.generalDescription: Hang Mua is a must-visit spot in Ninh Binh, Vietnam. It offers an epic panoramic view of the river and rice fields, making it a popular attraction for travelers. The area is also close to the river gateway to Hoa Lu, an ancient capital with significant historical sites like Buddhist temples and stone cathedrals. Hang Mua consists of two main spots: Mua Viewpoint at the mountaintop and Mua Cave at the foot of the mountain.

sources.snippet: Our trip includes a two-hour boat journey at Tam Coc Nature Reserve, or ‚ÄòHa Long Bay on land‚Äô, a photographic exploration of historic Bich Dong Pagoda, and a climb to Hang Mua, with incredible views over the paddies and river valleys of this beautiful region. We‚Äôll also be exploring some of the area‚Äôs fascinating craft villages to photograph the production of traditional ceramic art and stone carving. Learn the art of great travel and documentary photography while exploring one of northern Vietnam‚Äôs most scenic and culturally-rich provinces.

sources.shortName: Ninh Binh Explorer & Tam Coc authentic Photo Adventure

sources.snippet: Mua viewpoint is located at the top of a steep mountain, but the views are worth the 200,000 VND ticket, and the 500 steps up. From the top, you‚Äôll be rewarded with a 360-degree view of Tam Coc valley. The viewpoint is sometimes covered in mist but wait for it to clear, and you‚Äôll marvel at the patchwork quilt of green rice fields below and snaking rivers weaving in, out, and around the ancient karsts.

sources.snippet: The Mua Caves offer the highest viewpoint in the area, and it's arguably the best lookout in all of Ninh Binh. The climb of 500 steps to the top is worth it for the breathtaking panoramic views. At the summit, you'll find a majestic stone dragon overlooking the valley, with sights stretching across Tam Coc, Trang An, Ninh Binh City, and the vast expanse of rice paddies.

sources.snippet: The highest view point in the area and possibly the best lookout in all of Ninh Binh is from the top of the Mua Caves. The caves themselves are nothing to write home about but the 500 step climb to the top will be well worth the effort with panoramic views of the land. At the very top is a grand stone dragon who watches over the valley.

We first climbed the stairs leading to the beautiful little pagoda that sits at the top.

reviews.text:
Tam Coc, often called the "Ha Long Bay on land," is one of the most breathtaking places in Vietnam. Located in Ninh Binh, it offers stunning limestone karsts, lush rice fields, and peaceful waterways that make you feel like you've stepped into a postcard.

The highlight of Tam Coc is the boat ride along the Ngo Dong River. A friendly local rows the boat-sometimes with their feet!-as you float through three magical caves surrounded by towering cliffs and endless greenery. The scenery is so peaceful and beautiful that you won't want the ride to end.

Apart from the boat tour, Tam Coc has so much to offer. You can explore the ancient Bich Dong Pagoda, which is built into a mountain, or rent a bicycle and ride through the golden rice fields. The local food is also amazing, with fresh goat meat and crispy rice being must-tries.

Tam Coc is perfect for nature lovers, photographers, and anyone looking to escape the busy city life. Whether you're exploring caves, riding bikes, or just enjoying the peaceful views, this place will leave you in awe. It's truly a hidden gem of Vietnam!

A very cool experience! It's quite serene and unique - going with the row boat through the river, through a cave and then into an open space, surrounded by mountains.

The ladies rowing the boat are farmers I am told and after their work, they do this as an additional hustle. They row with their feet which is a sight to see, they're quite experienced.

Be warned! And be ready for them to hard sell you trinkets and souvenirs when they reach the end of the river (before turning back). We didn't bring any money but we felt almost hijacked when she wouldn't move the boat until she was truly convinced we couldn't buy anything. The other boats did the same thing, stopped the boat for about 10 minutes until someone bought something (or couldn't).

It detracted from the overall good experience from the row boat ride. We tipped her generously at the end when we were done and back in land where the money was available but we shouldn't have been held ‚Äúhostage‚Äù for quite a bit of time with the rower giving us a disapproving and unhappy, sour look because we couldn't buy her trinkets.

Bich Dong Pagoda is a serene and captivating site nestled among limestone mountains and lush greenery. The walk up to the pagoda is peaceful, with stunning views that get better as you climb. The pagoda itself is built into the mountainside, creating a unique and tranquil atmosphere that feels both spiritual and connected to nature. Each level offers something special, from ancient altars to breathtaking vistas. It's not overly crowded, which makes the experience even more enjoyable. A must-visit if you're exploring the Ninh Binh area and want a quiet escape steeped in history and beauty.

places.generalDescription: Thai Vi Temple is a historical complex dating back to the 13th century, nestled amidst picturesque mountains in Ninh Binh. Situated in Van Lam village, it holds great cultural significance as part of the Tran dynasty's heritage. The temple offers visitors a glimpse into ancient traditions and the story of Chen kings who built palaces for resting during their patrols. As part of the Tam Coc excursion route, it provides an opportunity to explore the sacred beauty hidden within the mountains and forests.

sources.snippet: Thai Vi Temple is located in Van Lam Hamlet, Ninh Hai Commune, Hoa Lu District. It is on the right of the Ngo Giang river and on the left of Coi Linh mountain, which brings the perfect harmony for thousands of years and creates Tam Coc as today, which is also known as ‚Äú shallow Ha Long  Bay‚Äù. Visiting here, we not only can feel poetic beauty of moutains and rivers, but also admire the fine architectural works which are typical of attractive ,original identity and made by ancient people.

sources.snippet: Thai Vi Temple, part of Vu Lam Palace complex in Tam Coc, is the worship place for Emperors Tran Thai Tong and Tran Thanh Tong, Empress Tran Thi Dung, and Generals Tran Hung Dao and Tran Quang Khai. When the Tran Dynasty was battling the Mongolians, they established the complex in Tam Coc‚Äôs mountains.

reviews.text: The first temple I saw the day I arrived in Tam Coc, near my homestay, lost in a beautiful landscape. I liked it very much. For me, no matter the size or style of a temple, there is always something about it.

After our boat ride we stopped by Th√°i Vi Temple.Tucked in the peaceful countryside of Ninh Hai, the temple is beautifully built with stone carvings, a lotus pond, and a well detailed dragon staircases.

The setting is calm and spiritual, with incense, blooming frangipanis, and views of the surrounding limestone hills adding to the atmosphere.

The entrance alone is impressive-ornately carved stone gates that open into a quiet sanctuary.

Tips:
‚Ä¢	Entry is free, though donations are welcome.
‚Ä¢	Wear respectful clothing if you plan to go inside the temple.
‚Ä¢	It's about a 10‚Äì15 minute walk or a short bike ride from the Tam Coc boat pier. If you buy a combo ticket as we did this was included.

The small caves were remarkable, featuring crystal-clear water and minimal light. We concluded our journey at a pool inhabited by buffalo. The landscape was notably more diverse, and we observed a variety of bird species. This tour was truly exceptional for a duration of two hours.

The ticketing process was quite confusing, as some women approached us immediately upon arrival. We paid 400 VND for a 40-minute boat ride. The view was beautiful, and the trip itself was relaxing-it's fascinating how they row using their feet. However, I didn't like how tourists were treated. The ticketing system lacked transparency, and at the end of the route, the women tried to sell us items and repeatedly asked for tips. It felt unsettling, as we were in the middle of nowhere, and the pressure to buy and tip made us feel uncomfortable and unsafe.

Not sure if there is standard price for this river ride but I bartered to 300k vnd. It was so nice, down the river through the water lillies, hardly anyone else on the river it seemed. Went through 2 caves which was fun. Lasted 1.25 hrs and seemed way less crowded or touristy the the other boat ride(s) in Tam Coc. Highly recommend

places.generalDescription: Thung Nham Bird Valley, nestled near the renowned Tam Coc Bich Dong tourist spot in Ninh Binh, is a hidden gem surrounded by tropical forest strips and limestone mountains. Home to around 40 bird species, including rare ones like the Phoenix and flamingo listed in the Red Book, this valley offers an enchanting experience for nature enthusiasts. Visitors can explore the area on foot or by bike, admiring beautiful gardens and diverse birdlife.

sources.snippet: Thung Nham is a less-known tourist attraction in Ninh Binh with foreign visitors since it is a bit far from Tam Coc, the main tourist hotspot, about 5 kilometers away from Tam Coc. You can get there by push bike, which takes half an hour from Tam Coc, or 10-minute ride on a scooter or car. Thung Nham is home to  50,000 birds of over 40 species, including cranes, phoenixes, storks, bitterns,  and some rare breeds listed in the Red Book that might be extinct soon.

sources.snippet: There are a lot bigger name spots in Tam Coc, but Thung Nham Bird Park is definitely worth on your list. It is possible to bike there, but tourists often opt for a taxi or a scooter. Thung Nham is home to more than 40 species of birds with about 50,000 birds including rare flamingoes, and even phoenix.

sources.snippet: Tam Coc, Vietnam and nearby areas are also home to many other appealing attractions, namely Co Vien Lau, Thung Nang, Thung Nham Bird Park, Thien Ha Cave, Hang Mua Cave, Bai Dinh Pagoda, Hoa Lu Citadel, and so on. These places are best visited on a day trip or a 2-day trip from Hanoi.

sources.snippet: From the sweeping rice paddies to the towering karsts, it might be easy to miss Thung Nham Bird Garden while visiting Tam Coc, Vietnam. I‚Äôm here to say that would be a huge mistake. The park is reletively new to Tam Coc tourism, but it has been constructed in such a tasteful manner.

reviews.text: The bird sanctuary park was amazing definitely worth paying the 150k to get into the park. Boat trips included in the ticket price. Visit caves, flower gardens, temples and more. Brilliant day out, worth hiring bicycles and cycling around as it's very far to walk the whole thing and scooters aren't allowed. One of the best experiences in Tam Coc. Go!!

Updated and corrected:
It's okay. 5/10. Nice views. Tourist prices, but that was to be expected. The entrance fee is 150k (it was increased by 50% from last years price. The boat ride to the buddha cave that is located close to the betrance is apparently free (I was just spooked by the entrance fee sign that was not clear if I need or don't need to pay. Would be nice if the entrance lady could mention it or put it on the physical map that you give out to the visitors.
I am unaware if the boat to the Bird Valley is extra or not.
Mermaid cave was greate and the viewpoint of the bird valley as well as the flower gardens were stunning.
You can spend here easily 2-4 hours.

This was such a lovely trip! I would say go closer to the morning time due to the heat. You can drive your scooter here or bicycle. It is very beautiful and you get access to a boat ride through a cave. There are some steep hills if you are walking or riding a bike. Cost 150k

places.generalDescription: Mua Cave, also known as a smaller version of the Great Wall of China, has gained popularity in Ninh Binh. Visitors can enjoy a leisurely climb up 500 stone steps to reach the cave.

sources.snippet: Mua cave is just a small cave in Mua ecoresort, where you could do a hard trek on steps up to the mountain‚Äôs peak for a great panorama of Ninh Binh‚Äôs scenic mountainscapes.It is good to connect your visit to Trang An or Tam Coc with a trek to Mua cave if you like trekking & having awesome photos.The best time of wonderful photos is between the late May & early June when the rice in Tam Coc turn its green colour to yellow one !. You have to pass about 500 steps to conquer the top of the dancing mountain, and the results  definitely won‚Äôt fail.

sources.snippet: Mua Cave is a hot spot of Ninh Binh in recent years, which has been dubbed the "Great Wall of Vietnam" as well as "check-in mecca" of young people. With over 400 mossy stairs leading to the top of Mua Mountain, you can reach the most convenient position to fully enjoy the scenery of Tam Coc region. The harmonious combination of nature and architecture will be a great experience for your spring trip.
sources.shortName: BEAUTIFUL PLACES IN NINH BINH FOR THE SPRING TRAVEL

sources.snippet: The Mua Caves offer the highest viewpoint in the area, and it's arguably the best lookout in all of Ninh Binh. The climb of 500 steps to the top is worth it for the breathtaking panoramic views. At the summit, you'll find a majestic stone dragon overlooking the valley, with sights stretching across Tam Coc, Trang An, Ninh Binh City, and the vast expanse of rice paddies.
sources.shortName: Ninh Binh Photography Tips: Creating Stunning Images at Famous Sites

sources.snippet: Many people flock to the Mua Caves to climb the steps and witness the best views of the area. What they‚Äôre not expecting are the jungle-esque gardens at the base of the ascent which consist of hanging vines and a very aesthetic footbridge passing over a small stream. Take some time with long exposure to enjoy this area before or after your trek up the stairs.
sources.siteName: Focus Asia and Vietnam Travel & Leisure
sources.shortName: 7 best photography locations in Ninh Binh

sources.snippet: If you are looking for a short mountain trek, amazing panoramic views and photos of a dragon on the mountaintop, Mua Cave gets to be your destination. Visit Hang Mua first to enjoy the cool air and the stalactites which are formed in many shapes and sizes. Then trek your way up to the top of Lying Dragon Mountain where a stone dragon statue sits.
sources.shortName: 10+ Amazing Things To Do in Ninh Binh

sources.snippet: The Mua Cave of Ninh Binh is located in the landscape of Tam Coc itself and is a popular stop on tours through the destination. Witness the bird's eye view of the landscape from the top of the Mua mountain, which is a stunning sight to behold. An altar dedicated to Goddess Quan Am also finds a place here.
sources.shortName: 14 Things to do in Ninh Binh Vietnam 2025

sources.snippet: Mua Cave is easily accessible, located less than a 15-minute drive from the renowned Trang An scenic area. The unique feature of this tourist spot is the long pathway on the mountain, designed to resemble the architecture of the Great Wall of China. Mua Cave with its winding mountain climbing path.
sources.shortName: Explore the breathtaking beauty of Ninh Binh through these stunning photo spots.

sources.snippet: Mua Cave is regarded as the place of fairy land on the earth. As it is perched above the magnificent Ngoai Long mountain, you have to climb up steep stone steps to get to the top of Mua Cave. The gorgeous views that can be seen from the top of the mountain will make the effort worthwhile, though.

Mua in Vietnamese means ‚Äòdancing‚Äô because it was said that Tran Kings used to visit this site to enjoy dancing performances. Mua Cave is exactly a place to get the most stunning view of Tam Coc.

places.name: Mua cave

reviews.text:
We biked here with no tour booked. Some locals will try and get you to park way before you need to, continue all the way to the ticket building and park there. (10,000 for 2 bikes)
Tickets were then 100,000 Per person and the climb begins. Really nice views, but lots of people. The climb was alittle steep at points but not too bad, when you get to the junction, the left route takes you higher. Overall a brilliant day. Allocate at least 2 hours for both climbs and the cave.

This place is absolutely worth a visit! The entrance ticket is around 100,000 VND per person, and the area is well maintained. The views from the upper level are stunning and truly rewarding. Be prepared though-the stairs are quite steep and can be slippery, even during dry weather, so wear proper shoes.

The hike to the top can be quite tiring, especially in the hot weather, but once you reach the viewpoint, the breathtaking scenery makes it all worthwhile. It's a perfect spot for photos and enjoying the natural beauty of Ninh Binh from above.

Highly recommended if you're visiting the area-just go early or late in the day to avoid the heat.

The view from the top of Mua Cave is absolutely stunning - especially if you go to the left side once you reach the peak. Truly breathtaking! That said, be prepared for lots of tourists. The lotus lake at the bottom is also incredibly beautiful and peaceful, definitely worth a stroll before the climb.
